Chapter 4. Convex optimization problems

Notation

  • R=R, the set of real numbers

  • R+=R≥0, the set of nonnegative real numbers

  • R++=R>0​, , the set of positive real numbers

  • Rm×n=Rm×n, the set of m×n​ real matrices

  • Sn=Rsymn×n, the set of symmetric n×n real matrices

  • S+n=R⪰0n×n, the set of (symmetric) positive semidefinite n×n real matrices

  • S++n=R≻0n×n, the set of (symmetric) positive definite n×n real matrices

 

4.1 Optimization problems

4.1.1 Basic terminology

An optimization problem in standard form is one of the form

(4.1)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

The set of points for which the objective and all constraint functions are defined is called the domain D of (4.1).

A point x∈D is called feasible if fi(x)≤0 and hj(x)=0 for all i,j. The set of all feasible points is the feasible set.

The optimal value of (4.1) is defined as

p∗=inf{f0(x)∣x is feasible}∈R∪{±∞}

(following inf∅=∞). If there are feasible solutions xk with f0(xk)→−∞ as k→∞, then p∗=−∞ and we say (4.1) is unbounded below.

A feasible point x∗ is called optimal if f0(x∗)=p∗. The set of all optimal points is the optimal set. If there exists an optimal point for (4.1)​, we say the optimal value is achieved, and the problem is solvable.

A feasible point x is called ϵ-suboptimal if f0(x)≤p∗+ϵ for ϵ>0. The set of all ϵ-suboptimal points is the ϵ-suboptimal set.

A feasible point x is called locally optimal if there is an R>0 such that

f0(x)=inf{f0(z)∣z is feasible, ∥z−x∥2≤R}.

If f0(x)≡0, the optimal value is either 0 (if the feasible set is nonempty) or ∞ (if the feasible set is empty). We call this the feasibility problem

findxsubject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

 

4.1.2 Expressing problems in standard form

We can solve the maximization problem

(4.2)maximizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

by minimizing −f0(x)​ subject to the constraints. The optimal value of (4.2) is defined as

p∗=sup{f0(x)∣x is feasible}∈R∪{±∞}

and a feasible point x is ϵ-suboptimal if f0(x)≥p∗−ϵ for ϵ>0.

 

4.1.3 Equivalent problems

Change of variables

Suppose ϕ:Rn→Rn is one-to-one, with image covering D. Then the problem

(4.4)minimizef~0(z)≡f0(ϕ(z))subject tof~i(z)≡fi(ϕ(z))≤0,1≤i≤mh~j(z)≡hj(ϕ(z))=0,1≤j≤p

and (4.1) are equivalent: If x solves (4.1) then z=ϕ−1(x) solves (4.4); if z solves (4.4) then x=ϕ(z)​ solves (4.1).

Transformation of objective and constraint functions

Suppose ψ0:R→R is monotone increasing on the image of f0, and ψi:R→R satisfy ψi(u)≤0⇔u≤0 and ξj:R→R satisfy ξj(u)=0⇔u=0. Then the problem

minimizef~0(x)≡ψ0(f0(x))subject tof~i(x)≡ψi(fi(x))≤0,1≤i≤mh~j(x)≡ξj(hj(x))=0,1≤j≤p

and (4.1) are equivalent: The feasible sets are identical, and the optimal points are identical.

Slack variables

Notice that fi(x)≤0 if and only if there is an si≥0 such that fi(x)+si=0. The new variable si is called the slack variable associated with fi(x)≤0. Then the problem

(4.7)minimizef0(x)subject tosi≥0,1≤i≤mfi(x)+si=0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

is equivalent to (4.1).

Eliminating equality constraints

If we can explicitly parametrize all solutions of hj(x)=0 using some parameter z∈Rk​, then we can eliminate hj(x)=0 from the problem, as follows.

Suppose ϕ:Rk→Rn is such that x∈Rn satisfies hj(x)=0 for all 1≤j≤p if and only if there is some z∈Rk with x=ϕ(z). Then the problem

minimizef0(ϕ(z))subject tofi(ϕ(z))≤0,1≤i≤m

is equivalent to (4.1).

Eliminating linear equality constraints

The process of eliminating variables can be described more explicitly when the equality constraints are all linear, i.e., Ax=b for some A∈Rp×n.

Assume that the original problem (4.1) is feasible, and let x0∈Rn such that Ax0=b.

Let F∈Rn×k be a matrix of which the columns are a basis of the null space N(A). Then the general solution of Ax=b is given by Fz+x0 for z∈Rk. Note that x∈N(A), i.e., Ax=0 if and only if there is some z∈Rk with Fz=x. Then the problem

minimizef0(Fz+x0)subject tofi(Fz+x0)≤0,1≤i≤m

is equivalent to (4.1).

Introducing equality constraints

Consider the problem

minimizef0(A0x+b0)subject tofi(Aix+bi)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

where Ai∈Rki×n and fi:Rki→R. In this problem the objective and inequality constraints are given as compositions of fi with affine transformations Aix+bi.

We introduce new variables yi∈Rki, as well as new equality constraints yi=Aix+bi for 0≤i≤m, and form the equivalent problem

minimizef0(y0)subject tofi(yi)≤0,1≤i≤myi=Aix+bi,0≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

This problem has ∑i=0mki new variables and ∑i=0mki new equality constraints. However, the objective (y0) and inequality constraints (y1,…,ym) are independent, i.e., involve different optimization variables.

Optimizing over some variables

Suppose x∈Rn is partitioned as x=(x1,x2) with xi∈Rni and n1+n2=n. Consider the problem

(4.9)minimizef0(x1,x2)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1f~i(x2)≤0,1≤i≤m2.

Define f~0(x1)=inf{f0(x1,z)∣f~i(z)≤0 for 1≤i≤m2}. The problem (4.9) is then equivalent to

(4.10)minimizef~0(x1)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1.
Epigraph problem form

The epigraph form of (4.1) is the problem

(4.11)minimizetsubject tof0(x)−t≤0fi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

which is equivalent to (4.1): (x,t) is optimal for (4.11) if and only if x is optimal for (4.1) and t=f0(x). Note that the objective function of (4.11) is linear.

 

4.1.4 Parameter and oracle problem descriptions

Parameter problem description

The objective and constraint functions have some analytical or closed form, i.e., are given by a formula or expression that involves the variable x​ as well as some parameters.

For example, f0(x)=12xTPx+qTx+r. Here, P∈Rsymn×n, q∈Rn and r∈R are problem parameters.

Oracle problem description

The objective and constraint functions are described by oracle models (which are also called black box or subroutine models).

In an oracle model, we do not know f explicitly, but can evaluate f(x) (and usually also some derivatives). This is referred to as querying the oracle, and is usually associated with some cost, such as time.

 

4.2 Convex optimization

4.2.1 Convex optimization problems in standard form

A convex optimization problem is one of the form

(4.15)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=ajTx−bj=0,1≤j≤p,

where fi are convex functions for all 0≤i≤m​, and hj are affine for all 1≤j≤p.

We may assume without loss of generality that aj≠0: If aj=bj=0, the j-th equality constraint can be deleted; if aj=0 and bj≠0, the j-th equality constraint is inconsistent and the problem is infeasible.

The feasible set of a convex optimization problem is convex, since it is the intersection of the (convex) domain D with m (convex) sublevel sets and p hyperplanes. Thus, we minimize a convex objective function over a convex set.

A function f:R→R is called quasiconvex if its domain and all its sublevel sets Sα={x∈Domf∣f(x)≤α} for α∈R​​ are convex.

A function is quasiconcave if −f is quasiconvex. A function that is both quasiconvex and quasiconcave is called quasilinear.

If f0 is quasiconvex, we say (4.15) is a (standard form) quasiconvex optimization problem.

The ϵ-suboptimal sets are convex for a convex or quasiconvex optimization problem, since the sublevel sets of a convex or quasiconvex function are convex. In particular, the optimal set is convex.

If the objective is strictly convex, the optimal set contains at most one point.

Concave maximization problems
(4.16)maximizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=ajTx−bj=0,1≤j≤p,

where f0 is concave and fi are convex for all 1≤i≤m. This problem can be solved by minimizing −f0. In a similar way (4.16) is called quasiconcave if f0 is quasiconcave.

 

4.2.2 Local and global optima

Any locally optimal point is also (globally) optimal.

Proof. Suppose x is locally optimal, i.e., x is feasible and for some R>0,

(4.19)f0(x)=inf{f0(z)∣z is feasible, ∥z−x∥2≤R}.

Now suppose x is not globally optimal. Then there is a feasible y such that f0(y)<f0(x) and ∥y−x∥>R. Consider the point z given by

z=(1−θ)x+θywhere θ=R2∥y−x∥2.

Then z is feasible and ∥z−x∥2=R2<R, so f0(x)≤f0(z). However,

f0(z)≤(1−θ)f0(x)+θf0(y)<f0(x),

which contradicts (4.19). Hence, x is globally optimal.

It is not true that locally optimal points of quasiconvex optimization problems are globally optimal.

 

4.2.3 An optimality criterion for differentiable f0

Suppose f0 is differentiable. Then x is optimal if and only if x is feasible and

(4.21)∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0for all feasible y.

Suppose f is differentiable. Then f is convex if and only if Domf is convex and

(4.20)f(y)≥f(x)+∇f(x)T(y−x)

holds for all x,y∈Domf​ (see §3.1.3).

Proof. (⇐) If x is feasible and satisfies (4.21), then f0(y)−f0(x)=∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0 for all feasible y. Thus x is optimal.

(⇒) Suppose x is optimal, but (4.21) does not hold, i.e., ∇f0(x)T(y−x)<0 for some feasible y​. Consider the feasible path z(t)=ty+(1−t)x for t∈[0,1]. Then for small t>0, we have f0(z(t))<f0(x), since

ddtf0(z(t))|t=0=∇f0(x)T(y−x)<0.
Unconstrained problems

For an unconstrained problem, (4.21) reduces to

(4.22)∇f0(x)=0

for x to be optimal​.

There are several possible situations, depending on the number of solutions of (4.22).

  • If there are no solutions of (4.22), there are no optimal points; the optimal value of the problem is not achieved.

    1. The problem is unbounded below.

    2. The optimal value is finite, but not achieved.

  • We can have multiple solutions of (4.22), in which case each such solution is a minimizer of f0​.

Consider the problem of minimizing f0(x)=12xTPx+qTx, where P⪰0 and x=[xy].

  • If P=[1000] and q=[01], then f0(x,y)=12x2+y→−∞ as y→−∞ for any fixed x.

  • If P=I≻0 and q=0, then f0(x,y)=12(x2+y2) and (0,0) is the unique minimizer.

  • If P=[1000] and q=[10], then f0(x,y)=12x2+x has a minimum at the affine space {(−1,y)∣y∈R}​​.

The analytic center of a polyhedron P={x∣Ax⪯b} is defined as a point inside P that maximizes the product of distances to the sides. The distance of x∈P to each side is (b−aiTx)/∥ai∥ so that the analytic center is x which maximizes ∏i(b−aiTx).

Problems with equality constraints only

Consider the problem

minimizef0(x)subject toAx=b.

We assume that the (affine) feasible set is nonempty. The optimality condition (4.21) for a feasible x can be expressed as

∇f0(x)+ATν=0for some ν∈Rp.

Proof. Let x be feasible, i.e., Ax=b. Then every feasible y has the form y=x+v for some v∈N(A). Therefore, (4.21) can be expressed as

∇f0(x)T(y−x)=∇f0(x)Tv≥0for all v∈N(A).

Since N(A) is a subspace, ∇f0(x)⊥N(A) ⇒ ∇f0(x)∈N(A)⊥=R(AT).

Together with Ax=b (since x​​ is feasible), this is the classical Lagrange multiplier optimality condition:

f0(x)+(Ax−b)Tν.
Minimization over the nonnegative orthant (e.g. 사분면 or 팔분면)

Consider the problem

minimizef0(x)subject tox⪰0.

The optimality condition (4.21) can be expressed as

x⪰0,∇f0(x)⪰0,xi(∇f0(x))i=0 for 1≤i≤n.

Proof. Note that (4.21) can be expressed as

x⪰0,∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0for all y⪰0.

The term ∇f0(x)Ty→−∞ on y⪰0, unless ∇f0(x)⪰0. Thus the condition reduces to −∇f0(x)Tx≥0. But x⪰0 and ∇f0(x)⪰0, so we must have ∇f0(x)Tx=0.

The last condition is called complementarity, since it means that the sparsity patterns (i.e., the set of indices corresponding to nonzero components) of x and ∇f0(x)​ are complementary (i.e., have empty intersection).

 

4.2.4 Equivalent convex problems

Eliminating equality constraints

For a convex problem, the equality constraints must be linear, i.e., Ax=b.

In this case, recall that (4.1) is equivalent to the problem

minimizef0(Fz+x0)subject tofi(Fz+x0)≤0,1≤i≤m,

where F∈Rk×n such that R(F)⊆N(A).

Since the composition of a convex function with an affine function is convex, eliminating equality constraints preserves convexity of a problem.

In many cases, however, it is better to retain the equality constraints, since eliminating them can make the problem harder to understand and analyze, or ruin the efficiency of an algorithm that solves it.

Introducing equality constraints

Consider the problem

minimizef0(A0x+b0)subject tofi(Aix+bi)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

We introduce new variables yi∈Rki, as well as new equality constraints yi=Aix+bi for 0≤i≤m, and form the equivalent problem

minimizef0(y0)subject tofi(yi)≤0,1≤i≤myi=Aix+bi,0≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

If we introduce new variables and linear equality constraints into a convex optimization problem, the resulting problem will also be convex.

Slack variables

The slack variables si associated with fi(x)≤0 give the equivalent problem

minimizef0(x)subject tosi≥0,1≤i≤mfi(x)+si=0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

Since equality constraint must be affine in a convex problem, we must have fi affine for 1≤i≤m.

Epigraph problem form

The epigraph form of (4.1) is the problem

minimizetsubject tof0(x)−t≤0fi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

The objective is linear (hence convex) and the new constraint f0(x)−t​ is also convex, so the epigraph form problem is convex as well.

The epigraph form of a convex problem has several practical uses. We can simplify theoretical analysis. It can also simplify algorithm development.

Minimizing over some variables

Suppose x∈Rn is partitioned as x=(x1,x2) with xi∈Rni and n1+n2=n. Consider the problem

(4.9)minimizef0(x1,x2)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1f~i(x2)≤0,1≤i≤m2.

Define f~0(x1)=inf{f0(x1,z)∣f~i(z)≤0 for 1≤i≤m2}. The problem (4.9) is then equivalent to

(4.10)minimizef~0(x1)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1.

If f is convex in (x,y), and C is a convex nonempty set, then g(x)=infy∈Cf(x,y) is convex in x, provided g(x)>−∞ for all x, (see §3.2.5).

Mimimizing a convex function over some variables preserves convexity. Therefore, if f0 in (4.9) is convex in (x1,x2), and fi and f~i are convex, then the equivalent problem (4.10) is convex.

 

4.2.5 Quasiconvex optimization

Recall that a quasiconvex optimization problem has the standard form

(4.24)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mAx=b,

where f0 is quasiconvex and fi are convex for 1≤i≤m.

Locally optimal solutions and optimality conditions

A quasiconvex optimization problem can have locally optimal solutions that are not (globally) optimal.

Nevertheless, a variation of the optimality condition (4.21) does hold for quasiconvex optimization problems with differentiable objective function.

First-order conditions for quasiconvexity

Suppose f is differentiable. Then f is quasiconvex if and only if Domf is convex and

(3.20)f(y)≤f(x)⟹∇f(x)T(y−x)≤0for all x,y∈Domf.

The first-order condition for quasiconvexity implies that x is optimal if

(4.25)x is feasible,∇f0(x)T(y−x)>0for all y≠x feasible.

  • (4.25) is only sufficient for optimality, whereas (4.21) is necessary and sufficient.

  • (4.25) requires ∇f0≠0, whereas (4.21) does not.

Quasiconvex optimization via convex feasibility problems

If f is quasiconvex, there exists a family of convex functions ϕt such that

(3.23)f(x)≤t⟺ϕt(x)≤0,

i.e., the t-sublevel set of f is the 0-sublevel set of ϕt, (see §3.4.5).

Let p∗ be the optimal value of the quasiconvex optimization problem (4.24). Consider the convex feasibility problem for a given value t,

(4.26)findxsubject toϕt(x)≤0fi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mAx=b.

If (4.26) has a feasible point x, then p∗≤t, and x is feasible for the quasiconvex problem (4.24) and f0(x)≤t. Conversely, if (4.26) is infeasible, then p∗≥t.

It follows that exactly k=⌈log2⁡((u−l)/ϵ)⌉ iterations are required before the algorithm terminates, since u−l2k≤ϵ.
